DataElement.preferredName: Diagnostic Imaging Primary Malignant Neoplasm Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Performed Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indication of whether or not the primary tumor site of patient was imaged.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Diagnostic Imaging Primary Malignant Neoplasm Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation._A malignant tumor at the original site of growth._Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders._A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis._Executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation..

Concepts.definition: Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation.

Property.preferredName: Primary Malignant Neoplasm Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Performed
Property.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor at the original site of growth.:Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.:A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.:Executed and carried through to completion.

Concepts.definition: A malignant tumor at the original site of growth.

Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine
